comments.text: A public bus gets you here. Very easy to get a ride, although most likely a short one. We got invited to stay for the night in Koda, which was amazing.
Still a good spot, lots of traffic and space. should be way to get to at least Marneuli
Most traffic is going to Marneuli, but it's fine to accept a ride until there and from there hitch on to Armenia.
Great spot.  Super easy.  Sign for Yerevan got me picked up in 5 minutes.
just arrived there and a guy ask me if he can help me..
I put a sign going to Gori and got picked up within 15 seconds.
Direct ride to Kutaisi. Great spot for north too. Use a sign.
Guy took me all the way to samtredia
Right in front of Gas station. Like 10 meters before it. Sign to Borjomi got me to the crossroad at Khashuri within 20 min.
Stood there with a fellow traveller right besides the gas station, really good hitchhiking spot!  The car took us to Gori, the exact place we needed to be.  Highly recommend!
Very quick to get a ride, but not a very long one.
Just walk past the off ramp and once the smaller highway starts, there is plenty of space for someone to pull over. Never waited more than 20 min here (10+ times)
On the "highway" without any problems to catch a direct ride to Kazbegi.
To Kazbegi

Picked up immediately direction Armenia, cars going slowly at roundpoint, nice shoulder to pull over and stop.
Use yandexmaps to see which bus will leave you here from Tbilisi.

Picked up immediately direction Armenia, cars going slowly at roundpoint, nice shoulder to pull over and stop.
Use yandexmaps to see which bus will leave you here from Tbilisi.
Good spot for going to Marneuli or Armenia
Sign for Gori had us picked up literally in seconds for a lift the whole way.  Great spot.
I was going to Poti but the first driver took me only to Kobuleti. It was a real problem to get out of town so I catched a bus to the Poti turn.
we got a hike to Kobuleti

Taking bus numb 10 or 101 from citycenter, this is the last stop, u have also a nice beach (small rocks..) to camp in the night. lots of traffic, easier cars than trucks (long ways, turkey-azerb so hardly stop)
Direction: Akhalkalaki, Vardzia - the road splits here. Both directions very easy.
Direction Ninotsminda
Yes, if you want to go to Kutaisi it's a long(ish) walk out of town. Not much space for cars to pull over, but, try anyway.
we walk from the train station to the crossroad near the gas station, there is a police station around. The walk took 30 minutes
DO NOT get off in the center of Khashuri because its a disaster to get out of it. if this happens stop Taxi and tell him to give you a ride till RIKOTI way. Taxi may cost some $7-8.
Just hitch after the bus stop and got picked up after 3 mins.
They are other people waiting for mashrutka. I wait 5 minutes, asking to go direction of Batumi. I went to Kobuleti 25 km far from batumi
Great spot for Tbilisi, right after the bridge, going south.
Great spot, just after the church across the bridge. Got a ride very quick, better for cars to stop away from all the tourists
Good spot with lots of traffic, and cars are moving slowly. We didn‚Äôt wait long and got a ride to Kobuleti.

It's a very good spot because there is a speed bump and then a bus station where the car can stop. As far I'm concerned, a marshrutka stopped and picked my friend and I (two males) up for free until Tbilissi! A sign is highly recommended :) be patient :)
After 10 min we got ride to Kutaisi :)

If you get a marshrutka to Carrefour, it's very easy to hitchhike north or east from just after the mall. There are a few spots with space for a car to pull over. This spot is often crowded with hitchhikers, but is still incredibly easy to get a ride. Last time I was there, a guy took 6 hitchhikers in his car and another car pulled over just behind him to take the other 2.
Sign for Tbilisi got me picked up within 20 minutes.
There's a small parking lot here with plenty of space to stop for people.

It's easy to hitchhike North or West from anywhere along this stretch of road. Bus 14 (from Rustaeli metro) and marshrutkas 32 and 41 stop here, among many others. You need to be careful to get off the bus here (tell the driver!!) because if you miss the stop the bus turns around and, you'll have to cross the busy highway or walk 10 minutes north to an underpass. If you're going north towards Gudauri/Kazbegi and a car going West stops for you, it will be really helpful to ride about with them to

You can hitchhike from literally anywhere along this highway between Tbilisi and the Russian border. People will stop everywhere, even when there is nowhere to pull over. Hitchhiking from Gudauri towards Tbilisi I never waited more than 15 minutes (10+ times)
USD-GEL exchange rate has changed, so the listed prices are even cheaper now

KAZBEGI (STEPANTSMINDA)

Kazbegi is in the North of Gudauri Ski Resort. If you need hostel to stay, choose the hostel called 'LOMI' which is in the center of Kazbegi. It costs 15 GEL ($10) per night. If you need to come back to Tbilisi try to hicthhike or take a minibus from the same Kazbegi center. Minibus to Tbilisi costs 8 GEL ($6). If you need any help, ask for it to the friendly Police Officers in the Police Station.
To Kobuleti - Batumi. Just before the police station there is a good spot. Waited 10 min.
Towards Kobuleti. Good spot, plenty of space for cars to stop in front of some factory. Waited 15min.

Nikortsminda is a historical village in Racha, Georgia (country) with XI century church in a village center, near a village are cave ,,Sakinule" and cave swimming pool cave, the river originates it's river ,,Sharaula". Also there are ,,Shaori" reservoir and place ,,Leknari" for two days hiking. Hitch Hiking is very easy in Nikortsminda, almost every point are good for stop a car and go to Oni or go to Batumi or Tbilisi through Terjola.
Walked a short distance down this road to find a better spot, and I was picked up and taken all the way to Yerevan.
All along this road there are places to stop.  A Sign for Yerevan is very useful.  Plenty of traffic going in all directions.
Good place to get to Tbilisi. Got a ride in 10 minutes
Only from May to August spot direction to Borjomi
As usual: just walk a bit out of town and start thumbing. This is Georgia - so drivers will stop for you even though there's not too much place to pull over.
In front of the airport. Possible to hitchhike in both directions, just be ready to say NO to a lot of taxis
we take a bus to Likani (only 0.4 GEL every half hour), left the town to the end and hike on to Akaltsikhe. As many cars along the road go to nearby town.
There is a good spot after the right turn on M27 just outside town. It took no longer than 1 minute to get a ride towards Novy Afon.

direction: Tsalka, Ninotsminda. take bus #34 (from Vagzali, train station) till the end (Tskneti). most of the people use not this, but the Marneuli road. however there's enough traffic to leave the city and it seems easier to get to the spot.

There is written that there are buses #84 and #64, but you can take any bus to Digomi district or Zahesi district or you can use metro to Didube station and from bus station take bus to agricultural university. I start hitch-hiking after Gldani turn (there is long bridge, so you will see it). after there is several turns but in most of cases drivers are keeping the main road.

if you want to Hitchhike from Tbilisi to west, to the black sea coast, first you should get out from Tbilisi by bus. You can take #84 bus from Tsereteli Avenue or #64 from Chavchavadze Avenue which goes out from Tbilisi and drops you on the main highway from which majority of cars go to the west of Georgia. You should get off bus on David Agmashenebeli Kheivani (Valley), the best one is to get off at Lukoil Gas Station and take a walk about 150 metres and start to hitchhike. You can say Hello in
from gori to west georgia. you canget out from the centre with a bus.

if you want to catch the ride for Kazbegi (Stepantsminda) which is in the Northern Georgia, the Mtskheta Highway is the best way to Hitchhike. Hold the Kazbegi sign with a little smile and you'll get the ride, though it may take some time. be patient and you'll get the ride.

GUDAURI

You can reach Gudauri from Mtskheta Highway by Hitchhiking. or you can take a Minibus from Tbilisi. (Gudauri is the most popular ski resort in Georgia.)

Gori Highway is the best place to hitchhike if you're going to the western Georgia especially. A lot of trucks and cars are passing this highway so you'll catch the ride easily. You can even catch the Turkish trucks going directly to Turkey so pick that up.
We only waited for five minutes and got a ride to Kutaisi center. The guy dropped us off directly at our hostel.
I put a sign going to Chiatura and it worked
I learned everyone can stop at the highway to pickup hitchhikers. Took a Bolt from Stalin's museum to here. I got picked up in a truck within 5 minutes going to Zestafoni
Good spot if you got dropped of the highway and going to Gori
Just after the roundabout there's room to pull over. First car that came took me to Batumi.
Direction: Turkey. Easy to get a ride, but lots of short ones.
Direction: Vardzia, Akhalkalaki.
Direction: Batumi.
Direction: Kutaisi, Batumi.

Direction: Gori, Kutaisi. We got lucky right after the gas station here. Cars getting out of it are slow, it seems to be a much better tactic then thumbing by the side of the highway (lots of cars then, but way too fast).
He drove us 30 minutes extra to give us a good first impression of Georgia.
You can hitchhike your way to monastery, it is long hike. Driver took us there and also to Gori afterwards.

Direction: Akhaltsihke (east)

Mostly local rides, it might take a while to cover substantial distance (took us almost 10 rides to Akhaltsihke.

Public bus number 12 can get you there for cents (tap your card, Yandex Maps app can show the route).

The other marked spot is right in the city.
Cars go slow here. Good spot in both directions. 20 min with sign to Batumi brought me to Batumi.

How come noone reviewed this place yet. Its along the only east-west highway and at a round about. So everyone who is going everywhere is there and driving slow with lots of little cabins with vendors where people can pull in so easily and you have food for the worst case. 1 Minute with a Batumi sign and I was in a car in Kutaisi direction.

Stand close to the coffee stop but not too close. A bit behind so people can see and think about you already. After 10 min a group of people checking their car there for a few minutes spotted and discussed me during their wait and decided to take me to Borjomi. Loooots of room for cars to pull over.

Take the bus there, you can check it on G Maps. Its best to go to Armenia because it has no inner city traffic. Literally took me 1 minute. Lots of space for the driver and they are still slow due to a traffic light a few meters before the stop. Sign to Yerevan got me to Marneuli.

All cars going to Yerevan from at least Tbilisi come through here. That is why the spot is great. But it doesnt mean there are many cars in total. Walk the road a bit to find a good spot. Took me 30 min with an Armenian driver but there were like 10 cars per minute so be prepared for a little wait.
super easy to get a ride back into Tiblisi
Cars that drive here are usually taxis, but other cars will pick you up.  We got invited for lunch and had a great time.
Excellent spot just before the intersection. Had a direct ride all the way to Borjomi. One person.
Super easy pick up all the way to Ananuri

in first 5 minutes, two cars offered a ride to Tbilisi, and then got onto a car to Tbilisi. Since the spot is next to a church then all the drivers will be signing the cross while passing you which is a plus.
Ideal spot, before tunnel, traffic is quite slow and a lot of room next to road
Without any sign, my friend got onto the third passing car and i got onto the first one that was passing

After a quick visit to Tsalejikha bazaar, i continued east to Martvili. Most of cars turn left after the bazaar, seems like the main road. I went right and got short rides until Didi Tchkoni. If you tell drivers "Mukhuri, Kurzu, Martvili" they'll understand which intersections to drop you at.

Easy spot to Tsalejikha and other towns direction Martvili, but you will get asked for money, even by cars who are not showing their taxi badge. There's a cheap blue city bus n.4 going 10km away, check schedule on Yandex Maps. So after 30 minutes i realized i was looking too elegant, started acting funny i got a ride in 5 minutes. Again i had to put boundaries when these 2 young guys invited me to stay for the night then tried to invite themselves to the restaurant where i was about to use the m

It is possible to reach the Vashlovani protected areas near the border if you ask or catch some tourists' cars, they receive authorization at the Reserve's head office here in Dedoplis Tskaro - you can also ask for a ride and cook a meal there. So if you plan to go into the natural reserve you should register, while Kasritskali, El Dar, Kvemo Kedi, Sabatlo do not require registration.
Actually, i only hitchhiked locals to Kvemo Kedi and Kasritskali, where a lady hosting travellers took me home.

Starting spot to Dedoplis Tskaro and Vashlovani reserve. Come here by green bus 3 from Tsnori center. I got quick rides until i reached Kvemo Kedi last village. Beware it's the hottest municipality in summer.

There's a new highway here, they say it opened 2 months ago (?). ƒ∞t is not the shortest way from Telavi to Lagodekhi but vehicles driving long distances somehow prefer to take it. Come here on your way to Lagodekhi or opposite way, to Tbilisi, Telavi, Tianeti. Don't wait in Tsnori, that's a big waste of time (i did for 1h30') unless you wanna meet some friendly locals who will see less and less tourists due to Azerbaijani one-way-only border crossing and this new highway.

A priest picked me u

Silent roundabout with dogs sunbathing on the streets, careless of the few cars almost running over them.
Almost all cars turn left (north-east) to Zemo Kedi, only one in half a hour went straight to Kasritskali. I got ignored by the minibus to Sabatlo, the farthest village at 3:30pm, but I'm sure you can catch it earlier in Dedoplis Tskaro.
I continued to Kvemo Kedi by 2 different rides by couples of english speaking youth, i camped at the Caravan Camping (see Google maps), astonishing views.

Shortcut to Kasritskali, dirt road unknown to Google Maps, suggested by people in the last shop of Kvemo Kedi (next to Caravan Camping, see Google Maps). It's wiser to start walking and find a car on the way.
I waited here one hour and hitchhiked to both this (1car/10minutes) and the main road going southeast (1 car/5minutes). Seems like everyone stops nearby as 3 cars tried to help me. Finally, a turkish speaking lady said i should be very lucky to find someone driving all 8km, so i gave up an

Great spot for heading towards Armenia or any of the villages up the road. Not much traffic, but very broad road and easy for cars to stop, which many will do eagerly (as well as passersby being very curious about your plans).
Easy hitchhiking out of Vardzia back to the main road (note: high season - August 2024).
Good spot with ample space to stop and relatively slow traffic. Also used by local hitchhikers, and I quickly found a ride together with somebody who came walking to the spot.

Wonderful view, calm border with almost only trucks. Came from Kars, got a truck ride in √áildir, walked to the gas station where the tir parking guys do speak Turkish + Georgian so they can help you. Only 3 cars in a hour so better to ask truck drivers! Got a ride by a tractor carrying hay they took me to collect more hay uphill and showed me the first village, while a fourth car of dutch tourists filmed us from behind.

REMINDER * if you go to Tbilisi, trucks drive the Akhaltsikhe-Borjomi-Kas

Perfect distance outside town to hitchike to Gelati or Motsameta monestaries. Very wide road so cars can easily pull off. Got a ride after a few cars passed who took us right to the road to Motsameta, it‚Äôs a short scenic walk after that

I Hitch hiked on Sunday son people coming back to work.
The road is going up hill so car are going slow, we are visible from very far and few other places on the way
good spot
Waited 20 minutes. 4 cars stopped and the 4th was going where I needed to. Georgia has great hitchhiking culture!
Good spot to get to the Turkish border
Just randomly thumbed on our way to the centre and a car stopped.
got quite lucky, but a really good spot
Direction to Tbilisi. Good spot with place to stop.
I agree this is a strategic spot if someone takes you from Stepantsminda, a truck going to Yerevan took me after Ananuri where i continued east towards Sighnaghi
Good spot, a lot of cars go South grom Stepancminda
Good spot, a lot of cars go from Stepancminda. Tesla took us near Dusheti
Not the easiest place for drivers to stop if it‚Äôs a bit busy, but people will stop regardless.
to Akaltsikhe
No sign, perfect for a short ride that gets you to the road to Zubdidi
Good place to start going down south from Mestia, right after the gas station. Some cars might ask for money, so ask beforehand. We waited not even 10 min.

Firstly i got a ride to these intersection, then Levan took me to his home for √ßay, it was almost sunset and no car came for 2 hours, so he hosted me. -15¬∞ perception in the morning. I'm creating a couchsurfing profile for him üåå

Firstly i got a ride to these intersection with bus stop, then Levan took me to his home for √ßay, it was almost sunset and no car came for 2 hours, so he hosted me. -15¬∞ perception in the morning. I'm creating a couchsurfing profile for him üåå
to Ursguli, and had meadow and water to camp, transport slow down before up hill, we got another construction truck going near the pass, so we can walk downhill after that
took us longer to make the sign then getting a ride

one of the most easy place to go to north or west. 95% of passing vehicles goes definitely to those directions.
most common way from town: from metro Didube, the bus to Zahesi (#121) or the bu
Direction: Poti, Batumi. A bit of place to pull over, cars go very slow.

Right after the roundabout direction Poti - Kobuleti - Batumi. There might not be plenty of space for the cars to stop right after the roundabout, but this is Georgia and they always find the way :) . We were walking to cross the roundabout when a car offered to take us, so no waiting time at all!

Not that much traffic going there, lots of walking and waiting in the heat - most rides that took us just took us to the next village where the waiting game started anew. Couple of hours later though a van driver picked us up and brought us very close to Tbilisi!
we like this corner because all vehicles to Tbilisi or further (even to Istanbul !!!) slow down here for the turn.
Armenian truckdriver picked us up.  Really good pickup spot!

(KA) ·É©·Éï·Éî·É£·Éö·Éî·Éë·É†·Éò·Éï, ·Éê·É• ·É©·Éê·Éï·Éö·Éò·Éö·Éò ·Éõ·Éê·Éú·É•·Éê·Éú·Éî·Éë·Éò·É° ·É£·Éõ·Éî·É¢·Éî·É°·Éù·Éë·Éê ·Éó·Éë·Éò·Éö·Éò·É°·Éò·É°·Éô·Éî·Éú ·Éõ·Éò·Éì·Éò·É°.
(EN) usually, most cars passing go to Tbilisi.
Had to wait quite a while, maybe because it's full of tourists here. But our ride got us all the way to Tbilisi.
if hitching from Sighnaghi to Tbilisi consider visiting Bodbe monastery. 2 kms from Sighnagi, almost on the road. hitching is easy, as anywhere else in Georgia.
This brought me no luck to Tbilisi because there is so much inner city traffic. Better go further north where all cars go to Kutaissi or Tbilisi. A bus goes there.
The road leaving Batumi, opposite the port. Use a sign for Kutaisi or Tbilisi. The road is broad with no clear indication or lines but Georgian drivers are crazy so they'll stop anywhere.

Nice place, lots of cars and marsuckas if you can't get a ride. Stand right in front of the bridge, don't stand near the bus stop. The only thing is that it is quite hectic here, so drivers might be distracted.

direction: tbilisi.
after the big bridge there's a petrol station and some place to stop.

Came here with bus 337 front Tbilisi centre, after 15 min of waiting someone stopped driving us to road to Telavi. 
A lot of traffic, but also a lot of place for cars to stop. We hitched rights under the big statue. Overall good spot

It is probably best to walk to this spot when coming from the airport, because 80% of the traffic are taxis. From this junction on you can start hitchhiking to the west (to Tbilisi) or east to Armenia or Azerbeidzjan.

Got fast a car to Tbilisi. Drivers were stopping often. As a single female be careful, my driver was very annoying. Initially he had to drop me at the junction before Tbilisi, where I could get another ride to Stepantsminda, but instead drove me to Tbilisi. Luckily my friend managed to help me get rid of this dude. Good luck and the spot is really great to find a car!

This spot is great to find rides inbound Tbilisi and further; plenty of space for both cars and trucks to stop and all the traffic passes by this point. I got a first class ride from here from a driver headed to Baku, Azerbaijan. If You have questions please use the "Contact Me" section on my website www.claudioadrianodobre.com to get in touch with me. Hit the road hard ;)
Inbound Tbilisi and further (Azerbaijan or Armenia).
Walked on the road back towards Mestia for 4 hours. Nice scenerey. Got picked up then by a priest in it's 4WD. Thank god. Haha.
Roads are almost deserts, me too i walked a lot and the day after picked up by tourists jeeps. anyway amazing sights definitely worthy!
started from ushguli at 10 am, walked down 35-40kms and 6pm we finally fit into the 4th car. pretty low traffic, but it's possible and fun!
Got a ride to Tbilisi after waiting for 2 hours, lot of cars and some anoying taxis.

I was this spot many times, I always go  back to Tbilisi from there I sometimes go to short stops and sometimes long stops to Terjola or Tbilisi. From here is important go in central highway and then go Tbilisi way or Batumi way.
easy to hitchhiking.
Maybe not the best spot space-wise, but good enough for the cars to stop. Good point for going down to the coast (Poti - Kobuleti - Batumi). Waited 10 min.
Direction to Armenia
I walked out of the village clustered around the border. Traffic trickles out, but the 2nd car stopped.
Direction Yerevan. We walked from the border (one guy, one girl) and got a lift with a Turkish truck driver after around 30min. We were waiving our hands up and down all the way to this place
Hiked here starting around 7:20pm and got a ride with a guy who invited me to stay at his uncles for the night, 70km from Mestia. Next day, they drove me to Mestia :)
we got a hike even at 5pm, kind of lucky that late, we arrived 9km from Mestia at 10pm
Anywhere along this road is pretty decent.  Got a ride in a few minutes with a sign for Baku.

If you're going to Armenia and you're at this spot you've taken a little detour. But no problem, cars will stop pretty fast. If you have no luck, however, try walking up to the first gas station before Rustavi on the east-side of the road. The men working there are very friendly and will help you get a ride :)
There's a gas stop and a bridge. If you stay there, you can get a ride towards Gurjaani, or even Tbilisi.
Good spot for direction Oni!

I used this spot several times to hitchhike to Racha region. Get somehow to Tkibuli from where you simply walk, wald, walk and waive your hand on the way. Within the city, most people are likely to stay within the city. When you approach the end of the city, chances increase that somebody drives to Racha. Be aware, though, that this road is not really frequented. Once you are outside the city, cars are extremely likely to take you with them.

Somewhere over here, there is a small bus stop. You can simply wait there, waive your hand up and down and wait until somebody will pick you up. Got a ride as a group of 4 within 30min with just little traffic in summertime.

Depending on the season, this is a great spot to hitchhike to Tbilisi. I did it couple of times. As Ananuri itself is a pretty popular tourist destination (and other people will come from Pasanauri or as far as Gudauri and Kazebgi) there should be plenty of opportunities to catch a ride. It is not the perfect location though and people will drive a bit fast )) Enjoy!
Directions to Kutaisi - be ready to spend on the road more than 3 hours. This place is not like other Geirgia and I dont know why
You can hitchhike just after the fork. It took around 30 mins to get a lift to the border with Turkey [Blog Post](http://www.hobospirit.com/hitchhiking-from-batumi-to-trabzon/)
Spot within walking distance of Batumi that can be used for Turkey
Direction to Akhaltsikhe
The other direction out of Mestia towards Zugdidi: walk out of town and expect long waiting times (>1h). But possible with an early start.

after the ethnographic museum. Unlikely if it is a good looking 4x4 taking tourist, these vehicles ask for money for sure. We got a truck doing road construction and went 10km ahead uphill and hike on...
Agree. Indead quite doable to hitch to Mestia (first ride got me to Lia, second to Jvari and then on to Mestia all the way). Expect some waiting times.
Going north to Mestia, at least till Lia and Jvari very easy also after doable

Alternatively stand 600 meter before on the shoulder of the highway (on the other side of the river, close to exit to Mtskheta). Take Mtskheta-mashrutka and tell driver to stop there. Good enough place with lots of traffic.
to Batumi

Direction to Gori or Kazbegi. You can take the 11th bus to get here.
There isn`t a lot of place to stop, but Georgian drivers stop anyway (3 in a row for us :) )
I think it bit dangerous there, its occupied part of georgia, by Russia and there are a lot criminals.
I've waited some time but hitchhiking is okey there.
a bus from Marneuli to Sadakhlo picks up people along the road and it can even take us to the border post. It costs 1 GEL a person. Hop on when you see that bus.

When going to Armenia, it might be a good idea to find a ride before Sadakhlo, as most people will feel uneasy if a foreign-looking, strange person with a backpack wants to cross a border with them. Still, with some patience, you will always find a ride :)
back to Borjomi
there is meadow and water to camp overnight. We got a van taking construction workers for road ahead and got another 10 km
to Zuldidi
it is a small bus stop after a road junction that transport slows down
Long straight section of road after the train station. Not perfect for cars to stop but there is no traffic so it's no problem.  I hh'd towards Sukhum. It took no more than 5 minutes for me.
Just out from industrial area, harbour; not enormous traffic but good.

direction: omalo (tusheti). some guidebooks say there's a green kamaz driving to omalo almost every morning. i  was lucky, i could hitch it by around 9 am. otherwise there are almost only fully packed jeeps driving through the pass.

direction: gal/i, zugdidi.
trolleybus #2 takes you here.

To Batumi direction. Not sure if it's the best spot to leave Kutaisi but it worked for me. Some local was telling it's not good to go to Barumi from here but seemed fine.
Took us about 10 rides to get from Batumi to Akhaltsikhe. Lots of cars stop, but rides tend to be short. Also further towards Akhaltsikhe the road gets very empty (around Goderdzi Pass).

Not much space for cars to stop on this stretch of road. But this is Georgia, so it still works somehow. Direct lift to Kutaisi in 45 minutes.
Spot on the roadside. But basically just walk along the road until you find a suitable place to thumb.

The Zagari pass to Lentekhi and Kutaisi was closed in the end of November. Tourists picked me up and told me they only saw snow blocking the way after Ushguli. I hope it will reopen before spring. Not more than 2 cars come to Ushguli every hour from west, some of them don't leave Mestia, but the halfway villages! Bring food from Mestia, the minimarket are expensive in Ushguli.

Saw that most reviews around this road are a bit dated (>10 years). But also in 2024, hitchhiking eastward out of Ushguli towards Tsageri/Kutaisi remains an adventure. On the short distance, ongoing road constructions make it relatively easy to get short rides from construction crews in all sorts of vehicles. But where these end, traffic is very sparse and walking some of the way might be worth it, especially since the surroundings are just spectacular.
